name: 4,4-bis(dimethylamino)benzophenone
Reason: 4,4-Bis(dimethylamino)benzophenone has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for this compound is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The presence of two methyl groups can increase the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. Each methyl group may contribute around +10 to +20°C. Additionally, the two phenyl groups can also contribute to the melting point due to their ability to enhance π-π interactions and overall molecular rigidity. Each phenyl group may contribute around +30 to +50°C. The presence of two carbonyl groups can also form strong hydrogen bonds and rigidify the structure, contributing around +20 to +40°C for each carbonyl.
